title: Unintended change in behavior for state copy/commit between v1.12.0 and v1.12.1
body:
#### System information

Geth version:  v1.12.1 and v1.12.2

#### Expected behaviour

When I run the following code snippet, I expect both printed balances (that is, `b1` and `b2`) to be 42:

```golang
db := rawdb.NewMemoryDatabase()
st1, _ := state.New(common.Hash{}, state.NewDatabaseWithConfig(db, &trie.Config{Preimages: true}), nil)
addr := common.HexToAddress("0xaaaa")
bal := big.NewInt(42)
st1.SetBalance(addr, bal)
useCommit := true
if useCommit {
	block := uint64(0)
	deleteEmptyObjects := false
	_, commitErr := st1.Commit(block, deleteEmptyObjects)
	if commitErr != nil {
		return
	}
}
b1 := st1.GetBalance(addr)
fmt.Printf("b1: %v\n", b1)
st2 := st1.Copy()
b2 := st2.GetBalance(addr)
fmt.Printf("b2: %v\n", b2)
```

This used to be the behavior for version v1.12.0. Specifically, for version v1.12.0, the following code snippet prints 42 twice:

```golang
db := rawdb.NewMemoryDatabase()
st1, _ := state.New(common.Hash{}, state.NewDatabaseWithConfig(db, &trie.Config{Preimages: true}), nil)
addr := common.HexToAddress("0xaaaa")
bal := big.NewInt(42)
st1.SetBalance(addr, bal)
useCommit := true
if useCommit {
	deleteEmptyObjects := false
	_, commitErr := st1.Commit(deleteEmptyObjects)
	if commitErr != nil {
		return
	}
}
b1 := st1.GetBalance(addr)
fmt.Printf("b1: %v\n", b1)
st2 := st1.Copy()
b2 := st2.GetBalance(addr)
fmt.Printf("b2: %v\n", b2)
```

#### Actual behaviour

In version v1.12.1 (and v1.12.2), the first code snippet prints the following:

```golang
b1: 42
b2: 0
```

Is this an intended change in behavior? Or is this a regression due to changes related to the new storage scheme?

Note that the output does not change between the two versions if I set `useCommit` to false.

#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour

Run the above code snippet for v1.12.0 (second snippet) and v1.12.1 (first snippet) and compare the output.

@rjl493456442 Thanks for the reply and clarification!

Would the following rewrite of the code accurately replicate the old behavior?

```golang
db := rawdb.NewMemoryDatabase()
st1, _ := state.New(common.Hash{}, state.NewDatabaseWithConfig(db, &trie.Config{Preimages: true}), nil)
addr := common.HexToAddress("0xaaaa")
bal := big.NewInt(42)
st1.SetBalance(addr, bal)
useCommit := true
if useCommit {
	block := uint64(0)
	deleteEmptyObjects := false
	commitRoot, commitErr := st1.Commit(block, deleteEmptyObjects)
	if commitErr != nil {
		return
	}
	st1, _ = state.New(commitRoot, st1.Database(), nil)
}
b1 := st1.GetBalance(addr)
fmt.Printf("b1: %v\n", b1)
st2 := st1.Copy()
b2 := st2.GetBalance(addr)
fmt.Printf("b2: %v\n", b2)
```

This prints 42 twice, but I'm not quite sure if that's what you were suggesting.
It's correct, you re-create a new statedb after commit.

@rjl493456442 Thanks for confirming! Do you expect the rewritten code (that is, replacing all commits with commits that are followed by new state creations) to be significantly less efficient (with respect to memory and CPU usage)?

The rewritten code seems less efficient to me, but I don't have an intuitive understanding of what's going on under the hood. If it is less efficient I've also considered reducing the number of commit operations in my codebase (for instance, by replacing them with calls to `IntermediateRoot` where possible). However, I don't quite understand what operations require a commited state and have run into weird bugs in the past that were magically fixed by a commit operation... (Note that I'm only using in-memory databases in my codebase.) Could you perhaps give me some pointers?

Fundamentally, the final step of a state transition is the "Commit" phase, during which all pending state mutations are flushed to the underlying trie database.

A state transition aligns with a block's execution process. This entails establishing a statedb using the state root of the parent block, executing all transactions sequentially, and end in the invocation of the "Commit" phase. In the mean time, "IntermediateRoot" can be invoked arbitrary times, which just compute the state root at that point without flushing any mutations to database.

Regarding the efficiency, I don't think there is a huge overhead by re-creating a new statedb. All the newly mutated data will be cached in the trie database level, reading data from memory is a lot faster than disk read.
